Our precious cargo. (shouting) Khrustalyov! My car! The other committee members look at each other for a beat then rush off after him. Suddenly everyone's in a hurry.  93 94 95 20 May 2016 Draft 10 56.
We need equilibrium. Soon.
“Equilibrium”, bollocks. Give me chaos every time. Got more meat on it.

Beria arrives at his limo. Khrustalyov opens the door and gets in. An NKVD officer is in the driver seat, Khrustaly stays outside. He nods to his boss and heads into the dac Inside the car, the young waitress Beria saw earlier is cuffed to the car door. She's frightened. He smiles at he

I know. Sad times. The car starts but the courtyard’s a logjam of vehicles a trying to get out. Other committee members hurry to their vehicles, drivers holding open the doors for them. Svetla heads with an NKVD man to her limo. Horns start to blare. Political manoeuvering. NKVD men trying futilely to direc Then, in the chaos, NKVD men emerge carrying a plain wood coffin. They load it onto the back of a truck and climb i Beria gets out of his car. Stands solemnly. The others ar obliged to get out and show their respect. The NKVD clear path for the truck and escorts. Beria’s car following. He won the scramble. The others start their cars. Horns blaring, cars jostling

The last of the limos drive away. An empty road. Silence. Then - a rumbling, getting nearer. A CONVOY of NKVD truck coming up the road, through the gates, into the courtyard Armed NKVD MEN pour out, occupying the house and grounds. Kobulov barks into a loudhailer.
Comrades! We share your grief! You will assemble in the courtyard for further instructions!

Busts, portraits, furniture, files, are removed, and medi equipment from the outhouse. Stalin's turntable, the reco still on it, is loaded into a box, nailed shut.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 57. Some STAFF are already in a line in front of the house, others are brought out by the NKVD, including the chef an the doctors. Some have belongings, some nothing. A lot of orders are being shouted. People are frightened, confused A supposedly dead Stalin, in a dressing gown and slippers marched out. The chef turns to his confused neighbour.

His lookalike. I think his contract just ran out. The LOOKALIKE is taken round the corner to be shot. But t SOLDIER executioner can’t do it. Looks like HIM. Someone quickly throws a cloth over the lookalike’s head. Good. B A second lookalike is marched out. Another, third lookali clearly a younger, fitter man, makes a break for it. Clos of a young, fit Stalin running for his life away from the dacha. But we cut away before any mine explosion. In fact the explosion doesn't come...
Delov and Two NKVD OFFICERS search the kitchen. They disc Matryona, crouched between two gas stoves, her eyes shut.
Hey, you! On your feet! Matryona is hauled up and dragged out the front door. Now we hear and just about see a mine explode in the wood
The soldier and sergeant are asleep. Khrustalyov appears Pervak.
Attention! The soldiers dozily comes to attention.
At ease. You can stand down now. There's food in the kitchen.

Thank you, sir. They head down a long corridor with a kitchen at the end. Then the sergeant comes back into view, collapsing to the floor, unconscious. NKVD arms reach into the doorway fram our view and drag him out.  98 99 20 May 2016 Draft 10 58. The other soldier runs across the doorway followed by two NKVD MEN. It's messy. The soldier may have gotten away in the woods. We don’t know.

Loaded trucks pull out of the courtyard. We are with Matryona as the truck moves off. From her pov see Khrustalyov join Kobulov in the courtyard. They get smaller and smaller in the distance. Kobulov shoots Khrustalyov in the head. Other landmines go off.
Khrushchev is chopping vegetables. A tired Bulganin is sa the kitchen table.
So... Beria's introduced 'special measures' to 'reduce the panic'? Carrots. He looks at Bulganin, meaningfully, as if sounding him ou Bulganin passes him a couple of carrots.
It's good to prepare, get everything ready. He looks at Bulganin, meaningfully, as if sounding him ou
Are we talking about Beria or the stroganoff? Khrushchev goes over to his washing machine.
I built a big factory making these. Khrushchev turns it on. It makes a terrifyingly loud nois
(shouting over it) If Russia was a noise, then that would be it.
Not so good for washing clothes. Very useful for “conversations”..about Beria.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 59. A pause.
Look, it's important someone takes control.
Someone like Beria? The conversation is suddenly significant. Bulganin comes to Khrushchev so they can talk quietly.
It should certainly be someone who has the support of all parts of the party.
Like Beria?
Well certainly one of us.
So... maybe not Beria?
You're very good with that knife. It’s ...
(interrupting) I'm saying... maybe not be Beria... We should get rid of him.

Yes. Yes! And soon! Punish him! Stick him in a room with twelve big hungry, horny Serbians! Suddenly the washing machine comes to a juddery stop, interrupting Bulganin. The men stare at one another in pa Khrushchev tastes a spoonful of food, not yet ready to ea
Mmm. That is good. Delicious. The machine starts again. Khrushchev spits out the food.
Feh! Raw!
We should take acting classes. If Stalin hadn't killed all the actors. (MORE )
20 May 2016 Draft 10 60.

Look, I want to come on board, but we don't have the numbers. Suddenly the phone rings. Has someone been listening in? Tentatively Bulganin answers as Khrushchev adds some of t vegetables to a pot on the stove. We see Malenkov, Mikoyan standing next to him, by the win of his apartment.
Are you being factional?
We're cooking some food. Khrushchev grabs the phone.

I can see you, you know. We cut to reveal the two apartment windows look on to eac other, very close in distance. We see Khrushchev in one window, Malenkov in the other. MALENKOV (CONT’D) Looks like factionalism to me. Khrushchev grabs a spoonful of stew and stands at the win theatrically eating it.
Tastes like lamb stroganoff to me. Khrushchev hangs up.
Listen, I'm acting secretary general and I'm - oh, he's gone.
Jesus, squeal any higher and you'll burst your hymen.
They're being factional
So are we.
I’m Acting General Secretary. How can I be plotting against myself? Khrushchev closes the blinds.  100 101 20 May 2016 Draft 10 61.
On the committee it’s you, me, Kaganovich. Three against three. But there’s also Molotov.
But he’s on the... (mimes “headshot” ) ...list.

We tell him - Beria put him there. Beria killed his wife. Molotov’s revenge gets us FOUR. Khrushchev goes through to another room, and peers outsid through a window. His POV: in a different block to Malenkov's, Molotov stares out of his window, grief-stric
(epiphany ) He’s at home. I’d better get over there before Beria and his sausage- faced clowns do.... The washing machine stops again.
(furious, to the machine) You piece of metal shit! (to Bulganin) Look after the food... He rushes off, full of urgency.
What do I do? Add salt, right? That's what people who can cook do. We hear Khrushchev shouting back as he goes.
Recipe book's under the sink!
Khrushchev hurries down the stairs, out across the courty to Molotov's stairwell opposite. The elevator’s at the se floor and rising. He's out of breath but he’s on a missio He takes the stairs.
Prisoner POV of Beria's face. He's close again. Too close He's quietly singing a traditional Russian folk song.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 62.
"In a field a birch tree stood..." No? Come, your voice was once so beautiful, Paulina Molitova. He clicks his fingers, “remembers”.
Oh yes. Meant to say. Stalin's dead! We open up to reveal a woman - POLINA - in her late 50s, in a tiny, barren cell. She looks haggard, wrecked.
(shocked) No! Our Stalin?
Yes, “your” Stalin. The one who put you here. The waitress and an NKVD GUARD are also in the cell. Beria hauls Polina up. She doesn't resist.

Come! Let's smarten you up. (to waitress) Sorry, darling. Work. I’1l make it up to you. (to guard) Fetch the mattress and have her washed. He walks Polina out while Ilyin and another NKVD Man brin flowers, a rug and a jug.
Beria leads Polina down a corridor. An NKVD GUARD comes the other way, with Slimonov, handcuf
S...s...limonov, isn't it?
Yes, sir.
F..f..f£..farewell, Slimonov! Slimonov is led away.
Khrushchev wheezes up three flights, pausing for breath before disappearing onto Molotov's landing.

Khrushchev, exhausted and sweaty, reaches Molotov's door knocks. He tries to compose himself but looks quite ill. Molotov opens the door. He's been crying. Khrushchev barr through, pulling Molotov with him.
Christ, you look like you’re about to be bulldozed into a lime pit.
A few moments later. Khrushchev is over the toilet bowl. Molotov is stood behind him.
Do you want me to hold back your hair? Polina always used to do that for me.
I... wanted to invite you to tomorrow's committee meeting...
(snaps back) Why wouldn't I be at the meeting? Khrushchev flushes.
Beria and Stalin put you on a list.
(shocked, hurt) Stalin? I must have wronged him so badly...
Are you cracked? Beria wanted you out. But listen. We can honour his legacy by making sure Beria doesn’t...
Oh! No, no, no. This sounds like factionalism, Nicky. Stalin didn’t like...  20 May 2016 Draft 10 64.
(loses it) Stalin's dead. It's over. We have to act.

(crying) I can’t believe he’s gone... Khrushchev tries to flush the toilet again. The cistern hasn't filled up yet. He tries a couple more times. MOLOTOV (CONT’D) It takes a while to... Khrushchev gives up, keeps his voice down instead.
Come on. That fucking slug Beria had your wife killed. He can’t be trusted...
Molotov and Khrushchev walk back towards the living room.
She betrayed Stalin and she betrayed me.
Housekeeping!
Molotov and Khrushchev come through into the living room find Beria. Everyone's surprised.
(at the same time) What are you doing here?
We were just chatting about Polina.
Well, would you believe it?..
The treacherous bitch.
.«..Or: a wronged woman who was framed.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 65.
Come on, Stalin found her guilty! She collaborated with the zionists. Polina's at the doorway. Only Beria can see her. This is going to plan.
She was a criminal. I’m glad she’s dead... Molotov notices her in the doorway. They look at each oth The barriers drop - it's clear he still loves her.
(hasn't seen her yet) She plotted to poison Stalin... He sees Molotov heading towards Polina. He can't believe
Is it really you?
(full of love) I'm back, Vyacheslav. They hug, emotional. Beria enjoys it. Khrushchev tries to himself out of his hole.
But the evidence was flimsy. No witnesses, no corroboration... No... Khrushchev gives up. Beria puts his arm round Molotov and Polina. It becomes a group hug.

(to Molotov) I kept her safe. For you, Vyacheslav. (to Polina) And I kept HIM safe. For you, Polina. Beria throws a victorious glance at Khrushchev. Molotov breaks down, overwhelmed. Khrushchev tentatively joins the group hug.
Well done. Well done, everyone.
The young waitress from the dacha hunches on the bed of t spruced up cell. The door opens. Beria is there with flow
Hello, my sweet. He moves to the table, where a bottle of wine has been uncorked. He sniffs it lasciviously, eyeing her legs.
Mm. Everything at room temperature. Oh, lighten up. It could be worse. Be warned.

A miserable Khrushchev eats the stroganoff, occasionally looking out across the courtyard at the Molotovs, arm in Nina has a mouthful. Grim. Khrushchev sees her disgust, silently picks up both plates, scrapes them into a bin.
The waitress' frightened PARENTS wait. She appears - distraught, stoical. An NKVD GUARD hands the parents Beri bouquet. They hurry off.
RUSSIA IN MOURNING. A red flag with black border flies ab the walls of the Kremlin. Beyond it: Moscow, with more re and-black flags.
Our footage: NKVD ARRIVING IN VEHICLES, TAKING UP POSTS/MAKING ROADBLOCKS ON MOSCOW STREETS. MUSIC ENDS.
A Zis limousine arrives at the Kremlin.  114 20 May 2016 Draft 10 67.
Beria walks jauntily through connecting doorways from the end.

Malenkov being made up to look like a leader. He’s uncomfortable under studio lights as the PHOTOGRAPHER sna away and STAFFERS bustle in and out with business. Two MA UP ARTISTS blotting and repairing his make-up.
Comrade, I’ve scheduled telephone calls later with...
Then tell me LATER. Beria arrives, looks at Malenkov and laughs.
Almost perfect. Perhaps... an apple just here, in the mouth? Chuckling, Malenkov wipes his face with a towel.

I have something to tell you. (over shoulder) I’1ll be back shortly! A smiling Malenkov grabs Beria and walks stiffly with him into the middle room. He drops the smile to show his fury MALENKOV (CONT’D) Don’t you ever, EVER, do that again. Humiliate me in front of...I’m the General Secretary!
(deferential) I'm mortified. Genuinely.
Looking my best for the People is a duty. Malenkov walks through the middle room and into the third room. His walks still seems a little stiff.
Of course. Shall we...
(spotting Pervak) What now?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 68.
Apologies. The seating plan for...
Give it to Blavatsky. He’s an expert at sitting on his ass.
Shall we get onto..
Yes, the committee meeting. Item One. The lists. These arrests and “interrogations”. Do we just take them down a gear, or....
Hold off altogether?
What, “freeze” them?
“Freeze”? Excellent thought. Yes, we could freeze arrests, maybe even release some low-level prisoners?
Oh, fuck me. Really? Is this what the old man would have wanted?
Stalin was radical and popular.
Liberalisation WOULD be radical. Now Delov has edged a little way into the room. MALENKOV (CONT’D)

No, this is something I wanted to show you. Beria walks stiffly to the third room. Malenkov follows, if he was going to do anyway. Delov produces on a stand an iconic photograph of Stalin hugging a young girl on a balcony.
I thought, a photo of you and the girl. Continuity?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 69.
(delighted) Good idea. We show how we’re taking Stalin’s humanity forward...
(to Delov) Find this girl. They leave the room.
Moments later. Malenkov and Beria walking to the meeting.
My chief concern is admitting we were wrong. All those arrests. And deaths...
We were being loyal. I promoted Stalin’s truth without question. I can promote a new truth without blinking. An unblinking beat.
So, I’1l push on with the releases?
Alright, but proceed carefully.
Of course.
Fuck this up and I’1l have you shot. Beria says nothing. MALENKOV (CONT’D) Just joking. I was testing you.
Is that a corset? ANGLE on Malenkov’s body. A GIRDLE is apparent.
It's a girdle. Different thing altogether.
You wear it well.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 70.
But not worth raising with the Committee.
Several more Zis limousines arrive at the Kremlin.
The committee sit at a table in an impressive, high-ceili room. Malenkov is at the head of the table with his new hairdo and a smart new outfit. The room is dominated by a giant portrait of Stalin.
So, in accordance with... (re portrait) .--his will, I propose Comrade Malenkov be named Chairman of the Council of Ministers. And General Secretary of the Party.
(pompous nod) And I propose Comrade Beria for First Vice-Chairman, Council of Ministers. Those in favour. Beria, Malenkov and Mikoyan instantly put their hands up.

Wait. Those are two separate proposals. Comrade Beria is incredibly busy combining his roles as Minister for both the Interior and Security. It would perhaps be kinder for someone else to carry the happy burden of Vice-Chairman.
I thank Comrade Khrushchev for his concern but I can assure you that I'm capable of doing two things at once.
Well, it would actually be three things.

Let's move to a vote. (to Beria) On both proposals? Beria gesticulates as if to say 'Up to you'.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 71. MALENKOV (CONT’D) Yes, on both. Me as General Secretary and Comrade Beria as Vice- Chairman. All those in favour? Malenkov, Beria and Mikoyan raise their hands. Molotov jo them, then Bulganin and Kaganovich. MALENKOV (CONT’D) Carried... Grudgingly, Khrushchev raises his hand. MALENKOV (CONT’D) ..+-unanimously. Next...
(interrupting) We need someone to take charge of the funeral.
What about Comrade Khrushchev?
(looking at Beria) Where’s this come from?
Yes, good thought.
I formally propose that Comrade Khrushchev be given the honour of organising the funeral.
(to Beria) But that will tie up all of my time, won't it?
If I can do three jobs at once, you can at least do two.
But I need to be...
(interrupting) You wanted to honour his legacy. You told me last night, in the bathroom. Molotov winks at Khrushchev: he's doing him a great favou
All those in favour..  20 May 2016 Draft 10 72. Again, Molotov, Beria, Malenkov and Mikoyan raise their hands. Kaganovich decides to raise his hand.
(justifying himself) You'd be good at it. Bulganin raises his hand.
Carried... U... una... Then, grudgingly again, Khrushchev. MALENKOV (CONT’D) .-carried unanimously.
Thank you. I shall remember this. Beria looks to Malenkov.
(trying to be formal) Comrade Beria. Beria clears his throat, looks extravagantly at ease.

I propose a halt to deportations. The release of some existing detainees. And the suspension of arrests officially sanctioned three days ago... Molotov, Khrushchev, Kaganovich and Bulganin are shocked.
You dare wipe your shitting arse on Stalin's lists!?
Let's all stay calm... although what you just said is utterly ridiculous.
(angry) One of you look me in the eye and tell me you’re not heartsick at the relentless, pointless arrests. Death after death after DEATH. A charged beat as he looks around the room, defiant.
Gentlemen, I believe we must embrace a new reality.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 73. MALENKOV (CONT’D) (“wanker” mime) Yeah. “Embrace” it...
How are we going to explain all the people you very comprehensively arrested in the first place?
If there were errors, if people misguided us then we punish those who did the misguiding...
Arrest anyone who carried out a wrongful arrest? Lavrentiy, come on. We ALL signed off on that shit...
(thinks he can be commanding) Stalin destroyed the status quo and built a new one. He was radical.
This is deliberately being rushed through. We don’t have time to..
I thought you were in favour of a more liberal approach, Comrade Reformer. Khrushchev remains silent, roiling with conflicting emoti
We must step back...
All those in favour...
(interrupting) ...of pausing the arrests and executions and so on? Malenkov and Beria raise their arms. Mikoyan, reluctantly joins them. Bulganin, Khrushchev and Kaganovich look at Molotov.

I have always been loyal to Stalin. Always. And these arrests were authorised by Stalin.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 74. The rest of the committee follow Molotov’s lengthy logic increasing frustration. MOLOTOV (CONT’D) But Stalin was always loyal to the collective leadership. That is true loyalty. But he had an iron principle, undeviating, strong. Shouldn’t we do the same, and stick to what we believed in? No. It’s stronger still to forge one’s own beliefs into the beliefs of collective leadership. (a beat) Which I have now done. Molotov raises his hand. Kaganovich and Bulganin raise theirs. Finally, Khrushchev raises his hand.
Carried...
Good, I'll oversee...
(interrupting) Unanimously.

I'll oversee the releases. We have unloosened the Union’s great corset. Nikita, you've some swatches and bouquets to look at. A funeral doesn't organise itself. We stay on Khrushchev as Molotov leans over. Malenkov prattles on in the background.
(To Khrushchev) You've won! Do him proud.

(in background) Beria, I want you to put together a communique for the press. I'll supervise the transfer of the body. Comrade Bulganin, tell the army; Comrade Mikoyan, the factories and the unions...
Twenty prisoners, including the shot by 5 GUARDS and CHASOV. 119 Nervous Man, lined up to be  120 20 May 2016 Draft 10 75.
Long live Stalin!
Comrade Stalin's dead. Comrade Malenkov's in charge now.
Long live Mal... Chasov shoots him just as an NKVD officer, SHULGA runs up
Stop shooting! Chasov turns, but fires off one more shot. It kills the Nervous Man, who slumps dead in the background.

(indicating list) Amnesties effective immediately. Orders of Comrade Beria. We're pulling out. They hurry off to join their colleagues. The NKVD’s mobilising, heading off. The prisoners are left, confused

Close-up of Stalin’s face in his coffin. Pull out and hig reveal enormous hall with people bustling, making last-mi preparations. The UNDERTAKERS’ finishing touches: doing make-up, hair, moustache, polishing buttons. Huge flags hang from the ceiling. More are being rigged. Swathes of red, and flowe everywhere. Beria and Malenkov stroll along the other side of the hal

Interrogations are on hold. First time we've had a chance to bleach the cells. Also, I’ve signed off a few amnesties. Petty thieves, harmless idiots... MEZHNIKOV (mid 50s, fussy), the designer responsible for funeral, stands beside a frustrated Khrushchev (in a red armband with black borders) at the head of Stalin's coffi
Now, curtains. Ruched or not ruched?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 76.
Ruched? What the fuck is ruched? Mezhnikov demonstrates with the material under the coffin
Ruched. Not ruched. Ruched. Not ruched.

Why should I care? While you were hiding in your mama’s linen closet I was at Stalingrad! I ate rats. Raw rats. Didn't even cook them! Behind him, a nervous group of STEELWORKERS. Awkward, overawed. Khrushchev in his element with the Steelworkers
Ah, the Steelworkers. Some REAL men! Lads, come, come! Malenkov moves over to assert his authority. Beria spots line of girls and moves over to them.
Iron and steel are the very foundation of...
(to Steelworkers) Iron? IRON? Derisory laughter.

Capitalism was built on iron. STEEL - is the 20th Century. The Soviet Union is made of steel! And these! Men! Made it! Huge wave of suppressed applause, caught between joyous approval of Khrushchev and the solemnity of the place. Delov arrives with a group of sweet, very Russian-looking girls, aged 7-9.
You found my girl?
We can't find her, Comrade Minis... Comrade General Secretary. These are suggested alternatives.
(to Khrushchev) Find her!  20 May 2016 Draft 10 77.
I thought you bastards knew where EVERYONE was! Find her, camel-cock! Pervak is stood awkwardly behind him with Maria Yudina, t pianist. Khrushchev turns and switches into chivalrous mo
Maria Veniaminovna. Please. Forgive my language, but he IS... one of those. This... He gestures towards Malenkov who holds out his hand but s seen Stalin in his coffin. It hits her.
Stalin!
Yes. Stalin. Malenkov is left hanging. He joins in the solemn moment.
Sad times. Thank you for coming.

Oh, I can’t TELL you... the intensity of emotion when I heard. General ZHUKHOV - 57, imposing, covered in medals - strid to the coffin, booming greetings to officers in the hall. He's followed by some of his ENTOURAGE.
If it wasn’t for this man, I wouldn’t be here today. - He lent me his driver! Hah! (to Pervak) Pervak! Handsome as ever! Put you in a frock, I'd marry you myself!
(returning) Ah, the generalissimo.

So, what does a war hero have to do to get some lubrication round here? (grabs one out of Delov's hand) Christ! Where’s this from, a Polish flamethrower? Tastes like PISS... Slow-mo on Zhukhov as he drawls out 'Piss' with the capti  20 May 2016 Draft 10 78. “FIELD MARSHAL ZHUKHOV, HEAD OF THE SOVIET ARMY".
As the others talk, Mezhnikov shows Malenkov a choice of portraits of him on boards to pick from. Zhukhov reaches the others. He kisses
Nikita! Sorry to hear about your wife's affair! (off his reaction) She hasn’t had one yet but God, I like the look of her. Hah!
Yes, she is... pretty.
Zhukhov. So rare to see you away from a mirror.

Beria. Must be such a... (re coffin) ..-difficult time for you, hiding your happiness at a promotion. (to Khrushchev) Who stood down the army? Why have my men been sent back to their barracks? I’m smiling but I’m very fucking furious.
(notices Maria) Perhaps Comrade Yudina should prepare those precious hands.
Maria, I am mortified I cannot escort you, but... her hand.
How very friendly. You never kiss my hand anymore.
So lovely to see you again, Comrade Khrushchev.
Again?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 79.
I taught his wife’s niece to play.
Katya! Yes, we were both at the salon recital...
Oh, I LOVE the idea of you at a “salon”. You have a party trick? Burping the alphabet? She sets off, passing Beria who whispers at her.
So many... (mimes piano-playing) ..-notes. Like your one to Stalin. Which I have. She looks back as she walks away, rattled.
So who confined the army to barracks?
That nonsense was NOT signed off by the whole committee.
Ah, so it was only one idiot, not the full set. Malenkov has chosen the portrait he likes. He joins them.
What's going on?
Talk of the devil.
(to Zhukhov) The decision was mine supported by Comrade Malenkov...
(not sure what they’re discussing) We took a view. And made a decision...
We're discussing the city security.
I know.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 80.
(about Malenkov’s hair) Christ, did Coco Chanel shit on your head? (to Beria) Moscow will be boiling with people. Your pansy torturers won't cope, you know. That’s a job for MEN.
Oh, I have PLENTY. NKVD AND the...
Interior troops. Merged now, into this “KGB”...
(kissy lips) “KGB”. Even SOUNDS like a bunch of nancies.
We're controlling the crowd at source. All trains inbound to Moscow have been cancelled...
(interrupts) But... I'm the trains! I'm the fucking funeral, I... I should have been asked.
(to Khrushchev) Please, Sir. I need to go...
I think she needs the toilet.
(to Malenkov) You need the army here. Not Beria’s Keystone Cops.
Maybe we should see who can mobilise first. Oh. It seems to be me... He heads off before Zhukhov can answer.
(to Zhukhov) We've got this under control. (to Khrushchev) You: find me the right girl. (to little girl) (MORE )
And you: go to that lady over there and she'll take you to the toilet. He sets off after Beria. Delov heads off with the girls.
I need to punch someone.
May I suggest... Khrushchev nods at a stack of boards with a portrait of a very airbrushed Malenkov being carried past.
He looks like my auntie after two peach brandies.

(calls from by the doors) We're opening the doors! A line of MEN IN COLOURFUL AIR FORCE/NAVY UNIFORMS take position at intervals from the door to the coffin and bey We hear a large CROWD coming up the stairs. They pour in through the doors, a tidal wave of grieving humanity.
Our footage of queues outside the Hall of Columns.
Footage of crowds gathering all over Russia.
Our Kiev footage of people leaving their houses, traipsin down Moscow streets. We focus on a FAMILY; a mother, fath and their two young children.
Poor people, many in tears, walk along tracks, towards a barrier. NKVD MEN with machine guns stand by. Their senio officer is FEDIN.  125 126 127 128 20 May 2016 Draft 10 82.
No trains to Moscow! No... go... go back to your homes... The crowd of people turn around and trudge purposefully a the railway track. Among them is the family we saw in scl
Our shots of crowds growing outside.

head_text.subj: FOOTAGE OF HUGE CROWDS SNAKING UP THE STAIRS.

text: Our footage of the queue filing past Stalin.
Svetlana chatting to Bulganin and Mikoyan, who clearly ha to be somewhere else but feel obliged to talk to her.
..-Papa always spoke with great fondness of you two. “My hammer and sickle” he always used to say, although I was never sure which...
Never heard that before. How...gratifying.
I'd be the sickle. Sharp. Poor Comrade Bulganin here...well, see he even has a head like the blunt end of a ball hammer...
(off polite laughter) My father always used to say go to you two when I need advice.
Oh.
..or help...  20 May 2016 Draft 10 83.
(a hand on each) “They are true and loyal men.”
Any time. Any time at all. Sorry, we have to take our places. Svetlana alone. She leans over a balustrade, watching the grieving crowd. Beria joins her.

This is... real. Nobody’s making them do this. In the crowd below: grandmothers sob; a sailor removes hi hat out of respect but drops it. The crowd keep moving an scrabbles his way back to try and get his hat.
I don't suppose you want a chair? Beria signals to an NKVD man who approaches with a chair.
I haven't sat down since he died. He was too big. You have to stand.
(what? ) Yes. Beria signals “no”. The NKVD man leaves with the chair.
Do you remember Yuri?
(no) I remember everyone. It’s a gift.
I loved him.
(suddenly remembers) Yuri Zhednov! Yes, special to you, I know. Some unsuitable associates. Tragic, really. I’m so sorry.
I want you to bring him back.  129 130 131 20 May 2016 Draft 10 84.
(are you mad?) But, my chick, how?
You brought Molotov’s wife back.
She was... I'd kept her.....
You're returning so many people to their homes. I want ONE person. Is that really too much? A beat.
For you, I will attempt the impossible. He opens his arms to her. She awkwardly steps into them.
Thank you.
I hate seeing you sad.
(awkward) I hate that you hate seeing me sad. They hug awkwardly.
The crowd files past the coffin: ordinary citizens mingle with representatives from nations and regions carrying demarcated floral tributes. Andreyev and Sergei supervise music from a balcony.

head_text.subj: FOOTAGE OF DELEGATIONS, FLORAL TRIBUTES, CEREMONIES ALL O
SOVIET UNION, QUEUES, PEOPLE COMING UP STAIRS.

text: OUR FOOTAGE of the committee: Molotov, Kaganovich, Bulgan Khrushchev, Malenkov, Beria and, closest to the public, Mikoyan, who's crying. A large wreath nearly brushes his face. He sneezes. A film crew is recording.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 85.
(sotto) Fucking pollen. They should make gas bombs with this stuff. Molotov, sobbing heavily, looks across, sees him.
I know. I know... The wreaths and bouquets are getting absurdly big. One - the message "From the grieving people of Uzbekistan" on i only just fits through the large double doorway.
(to Malenkov) I think that's actually larger than the region itself. Malenkov’s little involuntary laugh. Molotov sees, disapproves.

(chiding Beria) Inappropriate. The Uzbek bouquet makes its way past. On the staircase, s mitres bobbing up and down, some very worn. A group of ORTHODOX BISHOPS approaching in full regalia. Shocked whispers from committee members. Not Beria. MALENKOV (CONT’D) No!
Jesus Christ! It's the bishops!
What are these bastards doing at MY
Did I dream the last 36 years? Are we doing the revolution again from the START?
The Church belongs where we left it. In a ditch.
Tell Mikoyan to sneeze on the bastards as they go past.
(to Malenkov) Did you invite them?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 86.
No!
Ask Beria if it was him.
Don’t order me around. (to Bulganin) Ask Beria if he invited the fucking bishops.
(to Beria) Did you invite the fucking bishops?
Yes. Bulganin turns back, chewing over Beria’s answer.
Well? Bulganin nods to Malenkov.
Yes. He did.
I'm going to give everyone in Red Square a voucher permitting one kick each to his stupid face.
(to Bulganin) Is he asking for more delicious hay?
No. He said something quite complicated about a voucher system.
This is rehabili... Listen to me! This is rehabilitation of the most counter revolutionary elements! He can't do that without the committee.
(taking over from Bulganin) He says you can't do it without the committee. Which is true...  20 May 2016 Draft 10 87.
(interrupting) I can cancel house arrests under article 31. Malenkov realises he is right.
(to Khrushchev) He can in fact cancel house arrests under article 31. The camera crew is on them again. They all look as solemn they can. The bishops pass the coffin, making the sign of cross.
(to Malenkov) Tell him that I... Actually, swap... Swap...
No!
Swap!
No!

We can make it look like it's part of the ceremony. A dignified Khrushchev steps forward. Malenkov motionless staring at NAVY OFFICERS struggling to get a too-high wre through the door. The officers back up, then advance solemnly in a squattin position. The wreath low enough to go through but still t wide. Khrushchev eases back into line.

(whispers to Khrushchev) If only someone had checked... The navy officers back up again with the wreath, then wal with it sideways and squatting. Suddenly, an angry voice, away from the crowd. Vasily, in full uniform, drunk, trying to get to the coffin. Arguing with SENIOR NKVD OFFICERS, one of whom has a loudhailer.
They're murderers! Murderers! Give me your loudhailer!...  132 20 May 2016 Draft 10 88. From their balcony, Andreyev and Sergei see Vasily. Serge turns up a dial and the music grows louder.
(whispers to Khrushchev) Did you forget to give him his sedatives?
.»-If you don't hand it over I'll shove it so far up your arse your farts will deafen Moscow! (to Committee) .»--I KNOW YOU KILLED MY FATHER!

(whispers to Bulganin) Tell them to get the steel workers. (to Malenkov) We have to go!... The whisper goes from Bulganin to Kaganovich to Molotov t Tarasov, who hurries off. Vasily, now restrained, getting louder.

head_text.subj: I WILL AVENGE MY FATHER, YOU

text: Some of the crowd are starting to notice. Sergei raises t volume a bit more.
Don't record this!
A group of STEEL WORKERS chat and smoke, putting on new overalls and caps bearing the hammer and sickle. Some hav medals. Tarasov runs in.

Quick! We need you now! NOW! The steel workers are confused - they're not ready. TARASOV (CONT’D) Are you actually made of steel? Now! Move! The NKVD bundle them outside as, frenzied, they put out cigarettes, haul on jackets and, in one case, trousers.  133 134 20 May 2016 Draft 10 89.

The steel workers emerge in a rush, trying to look dignif Some are still hopping along, getting dressed. Vasily struggling with officers. One has his hand over Vasily's mouth. A bite - ouch - he lets go. Beria, over his shoulder, sees the steel workers approach
Move, you hairy-assed sluggards! They all turn to go. The manoeuvre turns into hesitant ch Molotov’s in front.
Liars and revisionists! You killed Stalin! Molotov sets off and the others follow him. He's not sett a fast enough pace - those at the back bunch up.
Decorum, please..
Faster, you SNAIL.
(to Vasily, trying to be both quiet and loud)

Pursued by the NKVD, Vasily rushes up some stairs. Beria breaks from the line, speed-walks until he's pretty much out of public view then breaks into a run and heads the staircase. Khrushchev follows.
A quiet holding area. Some Communist LEADERS including ZH ENLAI, with their TRANSLATORS. Vasily rushes in.
Friends! There has been a terrible crime! Zhou EnLai's translator translates for the Chinese leader
My father - they killed him. They got a child to cut out his brain and send it to Washington!  20 May 2016 Draft 10 90. Zhou Enlai's TRANSLATOR stops, then carries on.
They’re ruthless monsters and sodomites! The translator is trying to get every nuance. An NKVD officer grabs Vasily and pull him away.
.-+.sucking the cocks and balls of New York Zionist queers in petticoats... The translator makes sure he does the insult justice.
The NKVD wrestle Vasily to the ground. Beria and Khrushch arrive.
I‘1l make sure you all stand trial and get garotted by your own lookalikes in Red Square...
Vasily. It's me. Beria kneels beside Vasily who tries to spit at him, but lying down, so the spit just drops back onto his face.
Syphilitic cannibals! Zoo animals..
I know about the dead hockey team. The pretence. The denial. Vasily stops struggling. He's accepted defeat.
Freak weather. (calmly) I want to make a speech at the funeral.
(To Khrushchev) He wants to make a speech at the funeral.

Oh, MORE good news.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 gl. The Dignitaries from inside the room quietly file out, an past Vasily and Co. VASILY. I'm his son. (flaring up again, struggling) Let me speak, you howling chimps... Zhukhov appears, pushes Vasily into the now-vacated dignitaries room and punches Vasily hard across the face, knocking out a tooth. Vasily falls to the floor, unconsci Zhukhov pockets the tooth.
I'll stick it under my pillow tonight. May even make a ruble. He smiles at Beria - that's how you sort things round her Beria notices that Svetlana's watching a few yards away, distressed.
Lana! He's my godson. I won't let anything happen to him. She turns and hurries off.
Something has already happened to him!
Lana! (to an NKVD man) Tell her I'll be with her ina moment. The NKVD man sets off after Svetlana.
(grabs Beria, and makes sure no-one else is around in the room) Not yet! (close, angry) You're bringing the Church back? What next? Are the Romanovs coming?
Don’t be hysterical. We are ina new reality.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 92.
Well don’t you sound fancy? You locked half the nation up. Beat them. Raped them. Killed them.
Yes, and now I'm releasing them. I put so many in jail, there are so many to let go. You won’t believe how many will be free. Millions! The revolutions continues...
Not true. You're just doing it to gain power. You bend and crack the truth, like it was a human body.

Oh, you want the “truth”? Let’s start with you calling the blameless Polina Molotova a Zionist spy. In her own apartment. I heard you. And so did my men. He taps his ear to indicate they were listening.
But she was found guilty. You FOUND her guilty.
Past tense. In those “old days” you pine for, Nicky, that dissonance would get you shot. Khrushchev starts to speak, Beria cuts him off.
More truth: you called that slut doctor Timashuk to Stalin's bedside...
That was your idea!
You initiated it. Again, there are recordings. A woman who denounced thousands of innocent doctors. Khrushchev is thrown.
We ALL signed off on those arrests.
You're old regime, Khrushchev. Counter-revolutionary. (MORE )
The man who fucked up the flowers and invited his bit-on-the-side whore to play at the funeral. Even though she swore to kill Stalin. Who’s now dead.
What are you talking about? Beria hands him Maria's note.

She wanted Stalin dead and she knows your family. It's lucky we now live in the new Soviet Union or you and your wife and children would now be a pile of dust on the floor of a crematorium toilet. Khrushchev reads the note. The colour drains from his fac
Khrushchev comes back down the stairs and into the Hall o Columns. He sees some bishops in the distance, calls to an NKVD gu
Get those boyfriends of Christ out of my sight! We see the Bishops being moved away. There is some applau coming from a section of the queue.
I see they agree with me.
No, Comrade Khrushchev, it’s because they’ve spotted him. He gestures over to the applauding section of the crowd. can just make out Beria walking past, enjoying the applau
Start the trains. The people can come to Moscow! Meanwhile Beria is enjoying his moment. He’s with Kubulov
The revolution continues! (to Kubulov) Now start the other one.
A black maria pulls up. Several confused PRISONERS, some beaten, some of whom we saw arrested earlier, get out. Th van drives off.
The provincial train TRACKS we saw earlier. Crowds are ca in front of the NKVD and Fedin with pictures of Stalin, candles, flowers etc. A whistle blows.
For Moscow! Train to Moscow! People rush forward.

The distinctive design we saw earlier. The woman turns aw from the window. She's heard something. The middle-aged m who was arrested has returned. He's been beaten. She rushes over and hugs him. His son sits awkwardly in a chair: it's the young man who betrayed him to the NKVD.
CROWDS clamber onto the train, including the FAMILY WITH CHILDREN we saw earlier. Excitement, people clambering on board. Train packed full.

A PRISONER and the NKVD Interrogator from sc 73. The cell door opens and a SOLDIER points a gun. The Interrogator m to allow a clearer shot at the Prisoner. But the Soldier shoots the Interrogator. The Prisoner’s relieved moan. Th Soldier shoots him too, and leaves. We hear O.S a success of unlocking doors, yells and double-gunshots  142 143 20 May 2016 Draft 10 95.
KHRUSHCHEV alone, slowly making his way up the stairs. He hear piano music. Someone practicing. He is trying to fin the source.
A small room full of images of Stalin, and some of Malenk
(holding out note) This your work, is it? Cut to Maria sitting as if in an interrogation, but with piano nearby.
Why? Are there spelling mistakes?
(suddenly furious) Don’t ever speak to me like that again or I'll break your fingers! (waving note) The ammunition you've given Beria. Linking us. Me, my family. Do you know what sort of man he is?
He’s releasing people from prison...
Releasing people was my idea! He rapes children! Did you know that? He's murdered millions.
Have you?
Have I what?
Raped children, murdered millions?

I do not rape children! (pauses, agitated) I am not Beria! I have... stood up against our enemies. I have been relentless in my defence of the nation and the party. And I have hated doing what I had to do. (MORE )
Hated it. But Beria loves every minute. I'm the reformer, not him! (trying to calm down) Why did you write that note?
Stalin killed my parents, my friends, Zinaida Reich, Kuperchinski.
You were friends with Kuperchinski? Christ! Anyone else?! He's furious. Maria tries to hide her fear.
I don't know. Rovik perhaps? We were friends.
Rovik?! How the fuck are you even still alive?
Comrade. Nikita Sergeyevich, you know me, I...
No I don’t know you. Don’t say I know you. But now Beria ties me to you, and you know how this works. They kill your parents, then your sister. And brother. And friends....
Yes. I know how you all work. For a beat it feels like Khrushchev might slap her.
Sparsely furnished. Vasily in vest and military trousers, practising his speech. Svetlana sits on the bed.
My father was a warm and mighty bear...
He was. He WAS...
That bear now lies cold. We, 170 million cubs, his weeping orphans. (MORE )
20 May 2016 Draft 10 97.
Russian cubs, Georgian cubs, Armenian cubs. Lithuanian cubs...
Do you list every nation?
Should I not? There's a knock on the door. Beria comes in.
How’s my precious guest? Vasily looks at him flatly, clearly still mistrustful.
Thank you for looking after him.
Of course. (offers him a hip flask) I brought you something to calm your nerves. Vasily hesitates. Beria takes a swig.
Vasily, I'm your godfather. I would never poison you. I'd arrange a plane crash or something. (he laughs, they don't)
Your jokes are always so.. clenched. Svetlana takes the flask from Vasily, gives it back to Be Vasily’s about to protest but Svetlana’s firm.
(to Vasily, at Beria) We agreed we would be presentable at the reception. Vasily sulkily agrees.
I hate being sober. It’s a terrible, terrible mood to be in. She kisses him and leaves with Beria, who’s impressed.  145 146 20 May 2016 Draft 10 98.
(CONTINUOUS )
Beria and Svetlana come out of the room and shut the door They walk away, leaving an NKVD MAN on guard.
(indicates speech) Going to “reaffirm” your father’s contract with the people. New rights. New liberties...
Why does everything have to be “new”? They go through into...
(CONTINUOUS )
A comfortable living room - the nicest we've seen. Firepl rug, souvenirs and gifts all over. On a table, a massive is open.
..."new” potatoes...”new” Spring Fashions...”new”... Beria hands Svetlana a long, long list from the file, indicates an entry.
Yuri's dead. March 15th, 1949. Attempted escape from Kolyma with twelve others. Executed. I’m Sorry... Svetlana bursts into tears, crumples.
But... you said you'd bring him back. You...
It wasn't possible...
You lied to me!...
It was outside my jurisdiction. He indicates the list. Vasily suddenly enters the room, looking for the flask.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 99.

My mind’s going everywhere, like a million clarinets! I need... He’s spotted the flask. Svetlana, furious, grabs it as Be silently signals to the NKVD Man to escort Vasily back in the room and lock the door. Vasily miserably complies.
(ignoring Vasily, and reading the letter) Signed by the entire Committee.
(tenderly) Sit down, Svetlana.
I’d prefer to...
(kind, forceful) Sit down. Svetlana refuses. She’s angry, scared, defiant, pacing.
We had to do some terrible things for the Union. Your father said: Always look in the distance, never at the mud and blood at your feet. But, Svetlana, if Yuri were alive today I’d be releasing him.
So you’re saying, all that... (indicates list) ..-killing was wrong.
(impatient) Many lies were told. Evidence was fabricated. Those responsible will be found and...
Shot? This killing machine is never going to stop, is it?
Grow up, Svetlana! The world out there is full of dangerous men in uniforms and dinner suits. I’m offering you and that...gabbling bowl of moonshine my protection.  147 20 May 2016 Draft 10 100.
We are not children! (rethinks ) I am not a child!
Oh you are. And I warn you, Svetlana. Stay by my side. Or you'll both be beaten inside out and strung up for the crows. By the others.
Why should I trust you?
Because I’m the only one who’s telling you - trust no-one else.
Can I keep this?
Of course. Svetlana, I am so very sorry.

You're just like my father. She kisses him tenderly on the cheek and leaves. He goes to a hidden DOOR and unlocks it. Goes up some dar and dusty stairs, to a small room. We see a mattress, a v with flowers, and an awkward teenage girl, crying. He smiles at her.
Oh no. I’m here to cheer you up...

A wall of noise. And bodies. It's the end of a dinner. Th dignitaries have broken into groups to smoke, drink and c Maria’s playing Chopin. We’re with Khrushchev as he weave his way round. Zhukhov is regaling DIGNITARIES with a war story.
The greatest enemy any soldier has to face? It’s not guns, or fear, or hunger. It's chafing... Svetlana is with Vasily who's smartened up and sobered up She scans the room.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 101.
I’ve made enemies of everyone here. Oh Christ, sober’s HARD.
(encouraging) You're doing well. I almost believe that smile.

It’s easy. All I have to do is say hello, shake their hands, and not call them cunts. The HUNGARIAN PRESIDENT comes up to them, shakes hands. Vasily’s about to say something... We’re now with Beria as he enters the room, creating a gravitational pull. Back with Vasily and Svetlana.
All of Hungary sends you our deepest condolences. Anything you want from us, just ask.
Vasily, anything you want from Hungary?
A horse, I would like. Big horse. Khrushchev comes into the room and looks around. DELOV co up to him with a spotty, awkward TEENAGE GIRL.
Comrade Minister. I've found her. Khrushchev looks at her, full of contempt.
She's too big! She looks like a baby giraffe fell down some stairs. Delov takes her away. Kaganovich and Bulganin join Khrushchev.
Heard you were “canoodling” with the pianist?
Yeah, she give it plenty of left hand, Nicky?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 102.
Did she sit on your Presidium?

(ignoring them) This is classic Beria. Nail the woman as a spy, link her to the man, nail the man. I need someone with an army. Now! Svetlana spots Mikoyan. He tries to avoid her gaze, but s insistent.
Comrade Sickle! You look very dashing tonight!
(disdaining Vasily) Thank you. I hope your brother isn’t armed this evening...
He’s not even loaded!
Fuck me! Mikoyan pretends he’s being called away. He's off.
“He’s not even loaded”?
(joining Zhukhov) Comrade Field Marshall. A word?
I’m in the middle of a... Khrushchev steering Zhukhov to a door.
(to Zhukhov’s companions) He either planted the flag on Hitler’s bunker, or knocked the bear out with one punch. (to Zhukhov) There’s an urgent military matter. He guides him away.
Bloody rude, actually, Nicky. It wasn't Hitler's bunker, it was Goebbels’. And it genuinely happened.  148 20 May 2016 Draft 10 103. They pass Bulganin, who’s a little agitated.
What’s going on, Nicky? They say the streets are heaving with people... Zhukhov and Khrushchev exchange a glance. Back with Svetlana and Vasily. Molotov approaches, his arms reaching out.
Here’s Molotov. A hundred rubles says he calls us ‘comrades’ then hugs us.
(to Svetlana and Vasily) Comrades!
(sotto) I’m not kissing him. Khrushchev steering Zhukhov to out the doorway of the mai reception and across the large stairway.
(conspiratorial) Could I count on you if someone we both know was out of control, dangerous...
(sotto) Yes! Wanted to deal with him for bloody ages. I'm in. Khrushchev shows them into...
Khrushchev and Zhukhov are alone.
(that was easy) Really? Good. Because he's planning a coup.
What? Come on, Nicky. He’s so pissed all the time he can’t tell his arse from his windpipe. Khrushchev pauses.  20 May 2016 Vasily? A beat. Draft 10 104.
We ARE talking about the same person. Yes?
Beria.
Beria? Well, someone's grown balls the size of Kremlin domes. Yes, bravo. Bloody Beria. How DARE that hookworm try to out-manouevre the army!
He wants to hijack my reforms, make the people love him...
The people are a pendulum of idiots. They can be made to hate him... (clicks fingers) Like that. But listen, Nicky... (closer) I’ve got the soldiers. What have you got..?
All I’ve got is the funeral, and flowers and fucking trains. Khrushchev picks up a phone.
(down the phone) Get me the Transport Minister... Zhukhov slamming doors, opening cupboards.
You’d think there’d be vodka. Even beancounters drink vodka...
(shushing him) Double the train services into Moscow. He hangs up. They head back the stairway to the reception.  149 20 May 2016 Draft 10 105.
Moscow’s full already. It’1ll be total bloody chaos. Well played, Comrade.
I'm the peacemaker round here and I'll fuck up anyone who gets in my way!
Cock the size of an atomic bomb.
Maria at the piano, playing. Beria leans in and whispers, cleaning his glasses.
So what does Nikita taste like? I assume it's shitty traitor, like you. What do YOU taste of, I wonder? She stops playing. Dramatic silence.
I will carry on if you step away from the piano.

(innocent, to the room) I always thought that piece ended in an odd place! Beria steps back from Maria and she carries on playing. Malenkov is with Delov and a LITTLE GIRL who looks very l the one from the picture.
Smile, sweetheart. The girl reveals terrible teeth. MALENKOV (CONT’D) With your mouth shut? (off her closed mouth) Lovely.
Now I must take my dog out. For an evacuation! Perhaps two! Molotov leaves.  150 20 May 2016 Draft 10 106.
(you're the biggest) When this is over, go home and drink vodka until you pass out. I never want to see you sober again.

We cut from street to street, and see them fill with peop Wider shots reveal them coming in all directions. Hordes people on narrow streets, getting very crowded. An NKVD colonel, ENTIN is having a quiet cigarette. He lo up. At the end of the street, the crowd are heading towar him. He's on a barricade made of trucks and armoured cars with turrets, manned by about 20 NKVD SOLDIERS. Entin motions for the loudhailer. It's passed to him. He addresses the crowd.
Halt! This is a secure area! Return to your homes, comrades! Now! The crowd hesitate but don't stop. Some hold images of Stalin.
(shouts ) We've come to see Comrade Stalin. Others in the crowd roar approval.
Please, stop! Or we will have to open fire! They're still coming. The streets are jammed, heaving. Pe straining, crying, children being passed over heads.
(to his soldiers) On my order, fire over their heads. The soldiers take aim. One of them shoots in panic. Panic in the crowds.
I have not given the command! Shrieking. Bodies being lifted. Some pick up rocks and st from the street.  151 20 May 2016 Draft 10 107.
Disperse! Go back!... The crowd begin to advance. Entin draws his revolver. People start throwing rocks. One hits Entin. He staggers back, bleeding. The crowd is almost upon them.
The soldiers and machine guns fire. The soldiers reload a keep firing, panicking. The screams of the crowd mix with the terrifying gunshots
It stops. Entin stares out, horrified. His POV: piles of bodies, mostly dead, some wounded: men, women, children.

head_text.subj: SPREAD, THE ROOM GRADUALLY EMPTIES AS OFFICIALS ARE SEEN
BEING INSTRUCTED TO HANDLE THE SITUATION.

text: Beria approaches Malenkov, followed closely by Khrushchev Malenkov is practicing for the photo, holding the girl up
What's going on?
(through smile) That moron put the trains back on. Rioting crowds. Fifteen hundred dead.
(putting the girl down) No, you're too heavy. She’s put down and taken away.
Beria’s men fired on the crowds. He’s out of control, Georgy, I...
(to Khrushchev) What’s between your ears? Sausage?  20 May 2016 Draft 10 108.
Oh, I think I know who the people will blame. (indicates self) The poor old shitsack in charge...
Georgy, look...
Delov, bring the girl back. I need to make an appearance.
Perhaps the army should be in charge of the railway stations. Delov brings the girl back as Zhukhov arrives.
Bit late now, eh Beria?
They were outside Moscow, on his orders!
My orders? They were... (points with girl’s hand) «..your orders! And starting the trains... (pointing at Khrushchev) ...-were his orders!
So, what are YOU going to do?
(to girl) What do you think, darling? You're the only one making any sense. They all gradually edge out the room to a quieter spot by staircase.
Someone is going to have to be the face of this fucking travesty.
That's easy: Khrushchev.
No!
You ordered the trains!  20 May 2016 Draft 10 109.
And your men shot the people getting off them.
He does have a point.
No he doesn’t. There is no point to Nikita Khrushchev. Malenkov signals - The girl is taken away again.
We should blame the security forces. Hothead officers on the ground...
(to Malenkov) God Almighty, can you THINK? Or can you only pose for portraits? I. Am. Security. You... (mimicking Malenkov’s open- mouthed surprise) -.-baked cod in a haircut.
Oh, says the fucking jellied eel...
Let’s all calm down. (to Malenkov) Even if you DO get blamed. We close ranks. We rehabilitate you, we...
Yes, it's the new Soviet Union now...
For the good of the party I ask...

You spineless rat! Fuck you! You’re just a bloated corpse we propped up and stuck in a fancy uniform. (to the room) You want to blame me? It's time all of you realised who kept the daggers out of your fucking backs! Show some fucking respect! I have documents on all of you. ALL OF
(to Khrushchev) 13th March, 1937. Zolotov trials. 42 dead, 173 exiled. Your signature. 5th October 1946. (MORE )
20 May 2016 Draft 10 110.
Katzenelson. 63 executed, 219 exiled. Your signature...
Beria. Enough.
(to Kaganovich) Radek, Skrypny, your own brother. Your signature... He gestures at Khrushchev, Kaganovich, Bulganin and Mikoy Malenkov is stood behind him.
All of you! I've seen what you've done. It’s a very! Fucking! Long! List! He scatters some papers on the floor. Silence. The commit stare at the papers.
(heading off) I think I saw some brandy out here...
Lavrentiy. We can put this right.
(calming down) We'll meet straight after the funeral tomorrow. We will find out who's properly to blame for this. Arraign the officers who fired. Yes?
Of course. Beria heads down the stairs. The others stand there, still stunned from Beria's outbur
We can just demote him. Make him Minister Responsible for Fisheries or something.
Do you know what you’re saying?
He's using you, Georgy. He'll use you and then he'll kill you. You saw those papers.  152 153 20 May 2016 Draft 10 111.
He pointed at you, not me.
He said “all of you”.
I was behind him. He went (gestures) “all of you”.
"All of you".
No. "All of you".
(demonstrates ) He said: "All of you".
All of YOU can kiss MY arse! Get mme the girl, I’m going onto the balcony.
Malenkov steps onto a balcony with the girl. Because he doesn’t lift her up, we can hardly see her.
Two cars parked, with their drivers some distance away. Kaganovich and Khrushchev lean against one of the cars.
Who will the people blame? Me or Beria? Who looks like he’s got blood on his boots?
(you? ) Oh, Beria. People will definitely blame Beria.
Molotov approaches on foot, with a small dog.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 112. MOLOTOV (CONT’D) You've killed hundreds, Nicky! You certainly got your big funeral!
I regret this already...
(interrupts) Get in the car.
What?
Can’t talk. Get in the car. Khrushchev and Kaganovich share a look - then get in. Molotov pulls his dog in too.
(RE dog) I see she moults. Molotov takes out a cuddly toy. The dog starts barking - loud, irritating - and jumping up, trying to grab it.
This- (waves the cuddly toy again, to more barks) -is for any hungry ears...
The car isn’t bugged. We'd see wires stretching to Moscow.
(looks out) The drivers. So... (close, menacing) Let’s do him in.
What?

(vigorously shakes the toy) Beria. The treacherous snake brought back the Bishops. And he brought back Polina. He expressly ignored Stalin’s orders. The man has no soul. He ordered his men to open fire. Genius, Nicky.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 113.
(just about keeping up with Molotov’s logic) Yes, Beria’s the murderer here...
Those who were killed must not die in vain...
This is how the Soviet Union was built. Not with Bishops. Today, Beria gets an eight-foot crucifix up his arse! The dog's still yapping.
I've had nightmares that make more sense than this.
The people who died are martyrs. You have to do it in... The dog has stopped barking. Molotov waves the toy again it jumps and barks.
Please. Can this fucking DOG be a martyr?
You have to do it in one go. Bang! Like in '36. Won't be easy though.
Zhukhov’s already got the army sharpening their bayonets...
And it’s got to be today. Only time the army’s in the capital.
Excellent. I’m in!
Good, good. We have a majority!
Yes!
You two, me, Bulganin...  154 20 May 2016 Draft 10 114.
(cuts in) You need Malenkov and Mikoyan too.
But... why?

It's what Stalin would have wanted. The Committee, as one! Act fast Comrade. Act fast or be dead. (to dog) YES. Uncle Nicky’s going to be dead if he doesn’t get a move on, isn’t he? Oh yes he is. Yes he is...
The committee, dignitaries, generals, Svetlana, Mezhnikov Kobulov wait in formal dress. The guarded coffin is nearb Khrushchev watches uneasily as Malenkov jokes with Beria. Svetlana comes close.
You promised to protect me and my family...
Of course. Always, my dearest most precious...
Well you didn’t. She slips him the piece of paper Beria gave her, leaves. Beria and Zhukhov appear, surprising Khrushchev.
So. Comrade Zhukhov and I have been conferring... Khrushchev looks appalled. Has he been betrayed?
All chums again now, eh? Onward!
He's come up with a plan for Vasily's speech.
It will go ahead but it “may” coincide with the fly-past.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 115.
(flooded with relief) Hah! Excellent! That’s an excellent idea! Zhukhov! The genius!

Let's give the old maniac the send- off he deserves. A general sense of bonhomie. Beria puts his hand on Khrushchev - it's a reconciliation. He then pats Khrushch trousers... Bang, it’s the tomato game again. Zhukhov finds it funny.
It’s what he would have wanted. Kobulov gestures to Beria who goes over to him, leaving Malenkov with Khrushchev.
Georgy... A 21-gun salute begins outside - the signal for the funer
We have to act today.
Let’s bury the old man first. Khrushchev is about to reply but is interrupted by Mezhni

Comrades! Please take your places for the cortege. Khrushchev and his allies take their places around the coffin. Beria and Malenkov are at the front, next to Khrushchev. Zhukhov is directly behind him.
Malenkov joins in, as before, expecting Zhukhov to allow to command the moment.
Lift!

Yes, lift, everyone.  155 156 20 May 2016 Draft 10 116. Everyone lifts and tries to get comfortable. Some have a shoulder under it, others just a hand. They start walking coffin forward towards the open door as a cannon fires ev few seconds.
(to Malenkov) Georgy! Georgy!
(CONTINUOUS )
They shuffle out into a solemn Red Square, packed with mourners. Zhukhov still pressing Khrushchev.
Is Malenkov on board?
Georgy’s in. One hundred per cent.

All or nothing now, Nicky, eh? They are now in full view of the crowd. The pall-bearers shift the coffin on into the mausoleum, helped by some SOLDIERS. Zhukhov takes a step back and salutes. We see an extreme long shot of Zhukhov saluting. His eyes flick upwards. He knows he's being watched. A colonel with bushy eyebrows - BREZHNEV, on a Red Square rooftop, puts down his binoculars. Khrushchev nods at Bulganin and Kaganovich: it's happenin
The balcony on top of Lenin's mausoleum. The committee members and dignitaries are stood in a line.

(struggling, in tears) Stalin's love of ...love of the nation... The people's pain... The pain of the people... Oh... We pan along legs. Chalk marks - initials of who's to sta where. A technician crouches out of view. Khrushchev's fo scratches an itch on his calf.  157 158 159 160 161 20 May 2016 Draft 10 117.
Brezhnev and MOSKALENKO walk with briefcases towards some NKVD MEN by a set of double doors. An NKVD lieutenant, Pervak salutes them. They show papers, hand over pistols, inside.
Malenkov’s delivery is incredibly dull.

Yet we will draw strength from the continuity of the revolution as it goes on an on, generation after generation... yet today we pause in grief, and sorrow. But is not a pause in itself part of the revolution...? Beria looks bored. Others sway to keep warm.
Pictures of Stalin and Lenin. Brezhnev closes the door. B men open up their briefcases to reveal wires, a small red light bulb, electrical equipment.
Vasily is now at the microphone. He shouts into it.

My father was a great social scientist! But we, the people of the Soviet Union, are not laboratory animals! No! We are laboratory technicians! The very noisy fly-over begins. He tries to shout over it
My father! Your father! Our father!

Moskalenko fixes the lightbulb to a window frame. Brezhne trails a wire along the edge of the skirting board toward set of double-doors into a larger meeting room, with chai around a long oak table.  162 163 164 165 166 167 20 May 2016 Draft 10 118.
Beria speaking, Malenkov and Khrushchev on either side.
We must embrace our terrible loss with the strength and love for our nation that Stalin himself..

Moskalenko hammers a wedge into the window frame, checks jammed shut, as NKVD GUARDS listen to Beria's speech in a courtyard outside, their backs to the window. Brezhnev fastens a button underneath the table, checks a leading down the table leg and under the carpet. He puts place card - “Comrade General Secretary Malenkov" at the of the table, where the button is.
Beria continues his speech.
We now carry forward the torch of revolution. I applaud the Central Committee, who have declared Georgy Maximilianovich Malenkov President and General Secretary...
Brezhnev presses the button under the table. Moskalenko i the red bulb. It lights up.
The committee members are feeling the cold.
.-We promise you rights and liberties, bread and peace. Everyone in the crowd applauds. A bit too much for Malenk
The view from the balcony of Red Square - the applauding crowd, the flags, the banners and portraits.  168 169 170 20 May 2016 Draft 10 119.
Beria walks cheerfully with Molotov, followed by the PRESIDIUM MEMBERS, Zhukhov - in army greatcoat - then Khrushchev and Malenkov.
"Bread and peace". I knew it would work. It was between "peace" and "sausages". The generals and ZHUKHOV reach the NKVD guards at the doo
Forgive me, comrades. Your weapons.
I think we can rely on the liberators of Berlin to use their weapons appropriately. Khrushchev peels off.
Just going to freshen my trousers.
Khrushchev heads into the toilet. Brezhnev and his men ar all there, waiting quietly. Nobody says anything. Khrushchev pulls out Svetlana’s Yuri note, soiled with tomato.
Khrushchev catches up with Malenkov in the corridor ahead the meeting room. Khrushchev discreetly hands Malenkov Svetlana's note.
Beria gave this to Svetlana. Let her know what you did to Zhednov. See? He’d shit on all of us. Malenkov grows pale. He quickly puts the paper in his poc
The snake. Alright.  171 172 20 May 2016 Draft 10 120.
I'll bring up the emergency motion. There's a button under the desk at your end. You hit it. Yes? Malenkov nods, nervously.
Yes. But just a demotion.
Zhukhov enters the toilet. Opens his coat to reveal Kalashnikovs. Brezhnev smiles. A presidium member walks i go to the toilet.
I didn’t do any... A hand is clamped over the Presidium member's mouth.
Malenkov is at the head of the table, Beria near the wind Outside, some NKVD GUARDS patrol the courtyard.
Malenkov. Malenkov looks at him, unable to say anything.
Let's start. (still nothing. He takes over) SHALL WE? Item One. The unfortunate events of yesterday evening... Khrushchev raises his hand. Malenkov doesn't acknowledge
It is clear that the regrettable deaths of many citizens hastening to the capital... Khrushchev thrusts his hand even higher, glares at Malenk
..-had several local causes...
Er, Comrade Khrushchev has the floor... Beria, perplexed, looks at Malenkov, who avoids his gaze.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 121.
Comrades, I propose a new Agenda Item One. “The conduct of Comrade Beria”.
Can anyone else hear that barking dog? I’ve lost my thread now... Malenkov just stares at the table in front of him.
I accuse Comrade Beria of centralising power within his Ministry at the expense of the Party and the Central Committee. Of betraying the Soviet Union to capitalist interests...
(to everyone) I warn you, Nicky. This petulant Wild West stuff will end very badly.
(indicating button) Georgy! Georgy! Malenkov just stares forward, unable to move.
Comrades, Perhaps there is concern at the speed of our reforms. But really, THIS nonsense? Khrushchev leaps up, rushes round to the button and hits hard, knocking Malenkov out of the way.
Arrest this madman! He’s out of control!
The red light bulb lights up.
Good luck, ladies!
Soldiers burst into the room, led by Zhukhov.
Hands in the air!  175 176 177 20 May 2016 Draft 10 122. Beria puts the palm of his hand on the window. The NKVD guards are too far away to see it.
On Beria’s palm, he's written: "ALERT".
Zhukhov points his weapon at Beria.
Hands in the air or bullet in the fucking face! Malenkov’s hands go up. Khrushchev slaps them down in disbelief.
(banging on window) GUARDS!!... Zhukhov hits him in the face with his rifle butt. Beria d to the ground, his pince-nez fly off. Zhukhov gets in clo
See? You want a job done properly, send for the army. He frisks Beria. The other soldiers keep their guns on hi
He's got a knife by his ankle. Beria stares at Malenkov, who starts to cry.
Beria is handcuffed on a chair, his face a bloodied mess.
Georgy... Malenkov, sat across the room, looks ashamed.
(to Malenkov) Say nothing.
Remove his belt. It's hard for a man to escape when his trousers are falling down.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 123.
Leave the man some dignity, please. That suit without a belt would be a disaster!
Gentlemen, rest assured I sense the strength of feeling in the room.
Shut up, you fucking tumour.
That man is responsible for the deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocents...
We all are...
Exactly. Collective guilt.
Comrades, please...
What happens now? Zhukhov mimes shooting Beria.
Zhukhov! (to Malenkov) We wait for Red Square to empty of NKVD...

Then I give the signal and we roll this barrel of shit out. The doors burst open. It's Kobulov and 2 NKVD lieutenants Pervak, armed and carrying trays of sandwiches and cold meats. They freeze. Everyone turns and looks at them. Zhukhov cl his hand over Beria’s mouth.
Sorry, comrades. Wrong room. They turn to go. Beria tries to call after them.
Those sandwiches were curling up anyway. (to Beria) Your lot can’t even do CATERING. (MORE )
(to room) Let's go.

Several trucks and armoured cars drive up. Soldiers leap and surround the NKVD, who raise their weapons. An army COLONEL walks over to an NKVD OFFICER. The NKVD officer gestures for the NKVD to lower their guns. The colonel hurries inside, followed by his men, guns coc
The middle-aged man arrested earlier is playing chess wit his son. All is forgiven. The NKVD burst in.
No! NO! He didn't mean anything! The NKVD march over to the son, grab him and head out.
The colonel and his men walk through. Kobulov spots them. Dives into a store-cupboard. The men head in after him. W hear shots.

Vasily lies on the bed in his ceremonial uniform, drinkin The door is opened by an NKVD OFFICER, who steps to one s An army GENERAL, a CAPTAIN and two SOLDIERS enter. The soldiers aim their rifles at Vasily.
No! NO! You can't!... The general fires his pistol into the wall by Vasily's he
You nearly fucking killed me and now I’m DEAF! You hear me, I’m
The captain hauls Vasily up, tears off his epaulets, his medals, buttons. He's been disgraced. They drag him out.
Do you know who I am? Do you know who YOU are? Who the fuck are you?  182 183 20 May 2016 Draft 10 125.

Some NKVD OFFICERS and Beria's terrified STAFF are being marched out at gunpoint by a group of soldiers. Vasily's dragged into the living room. The frightened teenage girl is hauled out of the hidden r MARIA is also taken out of another locked room.
Zhukhov peeks through the curtains. The NKVD have been replaced by Red Army SOLDIERS. Zhukhov moves across to Be and stands him up. Takes off his belt.
OK, Judy Garland. Let’s go. He hauls him forward. Beria's trousers start to fall. Brezhnev pulls them up for him and Beria grabs them.
If we could discuss this rationally...

(that’s a good idea) You're right. We should... (gags Beria) “Ooh, what's happening? My trousers are round my ankles but my cock’s not inside an orphan...” One of the newly-arrived soldiers hands Zhukhov a sack. H puts it over Beria's head.
Hey! Nicky! We agreed. A demotion.
Oh, it’s definitely THAT, wouldn't you say?

Remember when you took Polina away? How you must have enjoyed it. I’m certainly enjoying this, you cockroach. Beria struggles. Zhukhov punches him in the gut. He folds is held up by Moskalenko and Brezhnev. His trousers fall. Brezhnev pulls up Beria's trousers, puts them in his hand  20 May 2016 Draft 10 126.
Hold them!...
(taunting Beria) How’s the meeting going, would you say, COMRADE SACK? You're on a list now, fucker!
Stop this!...
Beria is led out the room, battling with his trousers.
Roudenko is in the basement, along with Konev...
You're putting him on trial? Now? I'm disgusted! And slightly impressed at your efficiency, Nikki.
This is all totally, totally, beyond any agenda...
Listen to yourself. What do you think is happening here, Georgy? Should someone be taking minutes?
We have to act instantly... Molotov bangs the table.
Bang! Over! Marxism-Leninism was born in flames! Let the fire of our vengeance consume all traitors and bastards!
No! I forbid it!...
You want the NKVD to spring him from jail? Things’d get a bit lively then...
Nobody wants civil war.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 127.
He will kill us all... Khrushchev tries to hand Malenkov a document.
Come on Georgy. Sign this or we're all dead.
He deserves a trial! The man deserves a trial!...

(furious) What about Tukhachevsky and Piatakov and Meyerhold and Mikhoels? Didn't they deserve a trial? And poor Sokolnikov. Who begged him to look after his elderly mother. That monster strangled her in front of him. I’ve killed a lot of people. I did it because it was my duty. That human turd killed for pleasure. Khrushchev puts a brotherly hand on Malenkov’s shoulder.
Georgy, we’ve gone too far now. The only choice we have is between his death or his revenge. Malenkov looks at him, pale and dazed.
I'm General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
That's right. You are. He hands him the document and a pen. Malenkov signs it.
From a distance we see the generals and Brezhnev dragging Beria. His trousers fall and he trips.

A bleak space. An improvised courtroom. On a raised stage: ROUDENKO, mid-40s in a judge's gown. N to him, Marshall KONEV.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 128. The Presidium and Committee members are there with senior PARTY AND MILITARY OFFICIALS. Armed SOLDIERS everywhere. Zhukhov, Moskalenko and Brezhnev walk Beria to the improv dock. Zhukhov removes the sack and gag.
You are all witnesses to a criminal travesty! Think what you like! You are STILL witnesses! Konev keeps banging.
I demand my rights under, under... article 43 of the... Stop banging, I demand to be heard! We are not savages!
YOU are! YOU are!
(weakening, to Malenkov) Georgy... Our wives... what will you tell your wife? And mine? The children?
Comrade General Secretary... Trembling, Malenkov looks to Khrushchev who nods. Malenko tries to read out a statement.
"Lavrenti Pavolovich Beria...'
You fucking traitor...
"Lavrenti Pavlovich Beria. You are accused..." Malenkov stops. He looks like he's going to faint.

Fucks sake! (at same time) (taking the document) I am a Marshall of the Soviet "You are accused of using Union, a member of... your position as Minister of the Interior to plot against the Soviet Union with the goal of forwarding the interests of foreign powers..."  20 May 2016 Draft 10 129.
Foreign powers! Which ones? The fucking MOON?
(over Beria) "You are also accused of 347 counts of rape, of sexual deviancy and bourgeois immorality, of acts of perversion with children as young as 7 years old...
Ah. Everyone in this ROOM is responsible for someone’s death. So let's find something exotic for old Beria. Beria stops protesting, completely knocked. He spots Svetlana, her eyes full of hate.
Svetushka...
(reading as quickly as he can) .--including the rapes of Luba Dolomaya, aged 12, Petra Nikova, 13
Khrushchev skips ahead, trying to shout over Beria.
Anna Laranskaya, Nadia Ranova...etc etc... Magya Holovic...treason... anti-Soviet behaviour...er, the court finds you guilty and sentences you to be taken to Lubyanka prison and shot...

(whispers to Beria) Shut it. Look, here’s “Exhibit A”. Beria looks down. Zhukhov is holding a knife to his ribs. Beria suddenly loses it, starts screaming like a little g Khrushchev calmly waves goodbye.  186 187 20 May 2016 Draft 10 130. Zhukhov, Brezhnev and some soldiers drag him outside. Cha are knocked over, there are screams and shouts. It's chao They've got Beria as far as the doorway. A shot rings out Then another. More screams. A burst of sub-machine-gun fi A shout of "CEASE-FIRE!"
Beria's body is in the doorway of the courtroom. He's rid with bullets, bleeding heavily. Svetlana spits on the body.
For Yuri. For my mother. Zhukhov reaches into Beria's mouth and pulls out a tooth.
(off their looks) Nearly a full set now.

Beria’s body is hauled out by SOLDIERS. They dump it unceremoniously, douse it with petrol and set fire to it. Everyone emerges from the building, registering the burni corpse with varying levels of coolness. They’ve seen some brutal things. But Svetlana is shocked, and moves away from the group. S looks like she may throw up. Khrushchev is now the centre of gravity. Everyone wants t in orbit around him. Grim wordless exchanges. Kaganovich close
Now we can turn the corner. Put the bloodshed behind us. ANGLE on Malenkov. He looks bereaved.
I worry about Malenkov though. Can we trust him?
Can you ever trust a weak man? Khrushchev agrees. They can’t. He spots Svetlana, walks o to her. Kaganovich acting as informal bouncer, keeping everyone else away.  20 May 2016 Draft 10 131.
I’m scared.
There’s no need.
I don’t know where...
Vasily’s safe. I give you my word, Svetlana, I will look after him. He hands her an envelope.
Here is your passage to safety, too...
(re envelope contents) Vienna?
Vasily must stay. For his own safety. We can’t have a drunken madman spreading conspiracy theories all over the world...
I could...

No. He stays. You must go, for YOUR sake. There will be a reckoning here. Your...story may not fit. One of these men might have to kill you... She’s shocked. Khrushchev needs her to look at him. She d
I might have to kill you. A stunned beat. Her bitter smile. She looks at Malenkov, Mikoyan, Bulganin...
I never thought it would be you.
Safe travels, Svetlana. A bow, he rejoins the group. Someone has produced vodka. corpse burns on.  188 20 May 2016 Draft 10 132.
Now we can turn the corner. Put the bloodshed behind us. They place a large electric fan next to the bin.
I worry about Malenkov though. Can we trust him?
Can you ever trust a weak man?
(nods agreement) No... He turns the fan on and tips the ashes out. We watch the ashes dispel in the wind.
Maria is playing a Mozart piano concerto.

head_text.subj: TOOK CONTROL OF THE SOVIET UNION

text: We pan up to a box, where we see Khrushchev smiling, in h element. Nina and some sycophants sit around him. We see Andreyev and Sergei in the control room. Something suggest Andreyev’s living in a new reality too - more anxious, surrounded by new equipment? Or more confident, bullying?
We stay on Khrushchev smiling. A young Brezhnev is behind him.
